column4: we need to see your fstab. please use http://paste.ubuntu.com
your mountpoint is wrong, when you mount normally, what is the mountpoint?
R3cur51v3 , edbian: i think i know where i usually mount it in
R3cur51v3 , edbian: i nticed when i try to unmount from the desktop, it says /media/32D4C784D4C748B5
R3cur51v3 , edbian: so the mount point is /media/ correct?
R3cur51v3 , edbian: so the mount point is /media/ or just /media ?
R3cur51v3 , edbian: i see. thanks . sorry if i messaged all 3 of u.
R3cur51v3 , edbian: when i typed cat * /media/32D4C784D4C748B5 is not in there
R3cur51v3 , edbian: so final advice is to create new folder called /mnt/datadrive
R3cur51v3 , edbian: and use that as mount point yes?
that would work, then use that for fstab and point transmission there (though the resume on tranmission would probably be broken again initially)
R3cur51v3 , edbian: but where do i create the folder? inside /home?
R3cur51v3 , edbian: yes i understand i need to create /mnt/datadrive. my question is where is this /mnt/datadrive should be? its a d drive in my windows
R3cur51v3 , edbian: sorry i dont quite understand the term partition, but if you are saying that it is a logical drive created when i installed windows, then yes
R3cur51v3 , edbian: oh absolutepath. okie i got it

R3cur51v3 , edbian: do i have to restart my computer? because right now the d drive is mounted and i think its using the wrong mount point. and i cannot unmount it.. saying something abt me not being root
R3cur51v3 , edbian: yes its correct. i used sudo blkdisk as indicated by the documentation

R3cur51v3 , edbian: do i have to restart my computer? because right now the d drive is mounted and i think its using the wrong mount point. and i cannot unmount it.. saying something abt me not being root
